title: Union push to expel Labor MPs over free trade deals
text:
"All we as rank and file members of the party are asking them to do is uphold the party platform or find another party."

He said it would require MPs to ensure FTAs provide job opportunities to local workers while ensuring foreign workers are not exploited and to protect wages and conditions, trades, qualifications, safety, and sovereignty.

The motion comes as shadow treasurer Jim Chalmers used a speech on Friday at the Australian National University to defend Labor's FTA decision, saying the agreements were of net benefit to workers and the nation as a whole.

With Indonesia set to move from the world’s 16th largest economy to the ninth largest in 2030, and fourth largest in 2050, it was a market that needed to be tapped.

"Despite its proximity to us and its impressive growth record, Indonesia represents just two per cent of Australia’s trade,'' he said.

"We should be doing better, and investing more in this important relationship, particularly now."

Labor MPs supported the FTAs in a special caucus meeting on Thursday despite a strong union campaign against the deals.

The Australian Council of Trade Unions argues the agreements facilitate the entry of foreign workers and leave the federal government prone to legal action from abroad via Investor-State Dispute Settlement (ISDS) clauses.

However, Labor MPs argued in caucus that the party's opposition to trade deals with Investor-State Dispute Settlement and labour mobility clauses, which is enshrined in the party platform, only applied if Labor was in government.

On Thursday, ACTU president Michele O'Neil said Labor had "made a mistake that will not be forgotten by Australian workers".

ETU Victorian secretary Troy Gray blamed Mr Albanese for the move, saying "this is a moment where the ALP needs competent, strong leadership. Sadly however, Albo has shown it’s just too hard for him."

In his speech, Dr Chalmers said Labor always preferred multilateral trade deals over "poorer quality" bilateral agreements and he acknowledged there were legitimate arguments for and against the deals with Peru, Hong Kong and Indonesia.

"We make these calls on balance,'' he said.

"We support these deals because we recognise that more and bigger markets can mean more and better jobs, as long as we get the details right and that’s why we are pushing for improvements."

He reiterated Labor would push for changes to better protect Australian jobs and introduce safeguards and carve-outs in ISDS clauses.

Trade Minister Simon Birmingham said the government would consider Labor's request to abolish a 1993 bilateral agreement with Indonesia which contained no ISDS safeguards and, if not abolished, could override the newly-negotiated ISDS clause in the FTA.

Dr Chalmers said he appreciated frustrations with global trade, and said the US/China trade war was an example of the flaws.

"The US has gained massively from its engagement in the international economy over the years and continues to do so. But the average US worker hasn’t necessarily felt enough of the benefits,'' he said.

"The better path forward, and the Labor way, is to combine open and fair markets with effective social and economic policies to ensure that parts of our community don’t get left behind.

"We want trade to work for working people, not at their expense."
description: Unions are backing motions that would expel Labor MPs who abandon job protections in free trade deals as anger rises at the party for siding with the Coalition.
